item.title: Leetcode 230: Kth Smallest Element in a BST
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode() : val(0), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x, TreeNode *left, TreeNode *right) : val(x), left(left), right(right) {}
 * };
 */
class Solution {
public:
    int kthSmallest(TreeNode* root, int k) {
        stack<TreeNode*> stk;
        // stk.push(root);
        TreeNode* node= root;
        while(!stk.empty() || node) {
            if(node) {
                stk.push(node);
                node = node->left;
            } else {
                node = stk.top();
                stk.pop();
                k--;
                if(k == 0) return node->val;
                node = node->right;
            }
        }
        return NULL;
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Given a binary search tree (BST), find the k-th smallest element in it.

item.title: Leetcode 235: Lowest Common Ancestor of a Binary Search Tree
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(NULL), right(NULL) {}
 * };
 */

class Solution {
public:
    TreeNode* lowestCommonAncestor(TreeNode* root, TreeNode* p, TreeNode* q) {
        if(root->val < p->val && root->val < q->val)
            return lowestCommonAncestor(root->right, p, q);
        if(root->val > p->val && root->val > q->val)
            return lowestCommonAncestor(root->left, p, q);
        return root;
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Given a binary search tree (BST), find the lowest common ancestor (LCA) of two nodes, p and q. The LCA is defined as the lowest node in T that has both p and q as descendants.

item.title: Leetcode 437: Path Sum III
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode() : val(0), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x, TreeNode *left, TreeNode *right) : val(x), left(left), right(right) {}
 * };
 */
class Solution {
    int cnt = 0;
public:
    int pathSum(TreeNode* root, int sum) {
        dfs(root, sum);
        return cnt;
    }
    
    void dfs(TreeNode* root, long sum) {
        if(root == NULL) return;

        test(root, sum);
        dfs(root->left,  sum);
        dfs(root->right, sum);

    }
    
    void test(TreeNode* root, long sum) {
        if  (root     == NULL) return;
        if  (root->val == sum ) cnt++;
        test(root->left,  sum - root->val);
        test(root->right, sum - root->val);
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Given a binary tree and a sum, find the number of paths that sum to the given value. A path is defined as any sequence of nodes from some starting node to any node in the tree along the parent-child connections.

item.title: Leetcode 501: Find Mode in Binary Search Tree
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode() : val(0), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x, TreeNode *left, TreeNode *right) : val(x), left(left), right(right) {}
 * };
 */
class Solution {
public:
    int maxFreq = 0, currFreq = 0, precursor = INT_MIN;
    vector<int> res;

    vector<int> findMode(TreeNode *root)
    {
        inorderTraversal(root);
        return res;
    }

    void inorderTraversal(TreeNode *root)
    {
        if (root == NULL) return; // Stop condition
        inorderTraversal(root->left); // Traverse left subtree
        if (precursor == root->val) currFreq++;
        else currFreq = 1;
        if (currFreq > maxFreq)
        {// Current node value has higher frequency than any previous visited
            res.clear();
            maxFreq = currFreq;
            res.push_back(root->val);
        }
        else if (currFreq == maxFreq)
        {// Current node value has a frequency equal to the highest of previous visited
            res.push_back(root->val);
        }
        precursor = root->val; // Update the precursor
        inorderTraversal(root->right); // Traverse right subtree
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Given a binary search tree (BST), find all the modes (the most frequently occurred values) in the BST. If the tree is empty, return an empty array.

item.title: Leetcode 530: Minimum Absolute Difference in BST
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode() : val(0), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x, TreeNode *left, TreeNode *right) : val(x), left(left), right(right) {}
 * };
 */
class Solution {
public:
    int getMinimumDifference(TreeNode* root) {
        TreeNode* prv = NULL; int ans = INT_MAX;
        stack<TreeNode*> stk;
        while(!stk.empty() || root) {
            if(root) {
                stk.push(root);
                root = root->left;
            } else {
                root = stk.top();
                stk.pop();
                if(prv != NULL) {
                    ans = min(ans, root->val - prv->val);
                }
                prv = root;
                root = root->right;
            }
        }
        return ans;
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Given a binary search tree (BST), find the minimum absolute difference between the values of any two nodes in the tree.

item.title: Leetcode 538: Convert BST to Greater Tree
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode() : val(0), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x, TreeNode *left, TreeNode *right) : val(x), left(left), right(right) {}
 * };
 */
class Solution {

    int sum = 0;

public:

    TreeNode* convertBST(TreeNode* root) {
        convert(root);
        return root;
    }

    void convert(TreeNode* root) {
        if(!root) return;
        convert(root->right);
        root->val += sum;
        sum = root->val;
        convert(root->left);
    }

};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Given a Binary Search Tree (BST), convert it to a Greater Tree such that every key of the original BST is changed to the original key plus the sum of all keys greater than the original key.

item.title: Leetcode 669: Trim a Binary Search Tree
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode() : val(0), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x, TreeNode *left, TreeNode *right) : val(x), left(left), right(right) {}
 * };
 */
class Solution {
public:
    TreeNode* trimBST(TreeNode* root, int low, int high) {
        if(root == NULL) return NULL;

       if(root->val < low) {
           return trimBST(root->right, low, high);
       } else if(root->val > high) {
            return trimBST(root->left, low, high);
       }

        root->left = trimBST(root->left, low, high);
        root->right= trimBST(root->right, low, high);
        return root;
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Given a binary search tree (BST) and a range [low, high], the goal is to trim the BST so that all values in the tree lie within this range. The trimmed tree should maintain the properties of a BST.

item.title: Leetcode 703: Kth Largest Element in a Stream
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

class KthLargest {
public:
    priority_queue<int, vector<int>, greater<int>> pq;
    int k;
    KthLargest(int k, vector<int>& nums) {
        this->k = k;
        for(auto x: nums) {
            pq.push(x);
            if(pq.size() > k) {
                cout << pq.top();
                pq.pop();
            }

        }

    }
    
    int add(int val) {
        pq.push(val);
        if(pq.size() > k) {
            pq.pop();
        }
        return pq.top();
    }
};

/**
 * Your KthLargest object will be instantiated and called as such:
 * KthLargest* obj = new KthLargest(k, nums);
 * int param_1 = obj->add(val);
 */

Problem Statement Link to heading

Design a class KthLargest that keeps track of the kth largest element in a stream of integers. The class should support the following operations:

item.title: Leetcode 938: Range Sum of BST
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode() : val(0), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x, TreeNode *left, TreeNode *right) : val(x), left(left), right(right) {}
 * };
 */
class Solution {
public:

    int rangeSumBST(TreeNode* root, int low, int high) {
        if(!root) return 0;
        int sum = 0;
        sum += rangeSumBST(root->left, low, high);
        if(root->val >= low && root->val <= high)
            sum += root->val;
        sum += rangeSumBST(root->right, low, high);
        return sum;
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Given the root of a binary search tree (BST) and two integers low and high, the task is to return the sum of the values of all nodes with values in the inclusive range [low, high].

item.title: Leetcode 98: Validate Binary Search Tree
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

/**
 * Definition for a binary tree node.
 * struct TreeNode {
 *     int val;
 *     TreeNode *left;
 *     TreeNode *right;
 *     TreeNode() : val(0), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x) : val(x), left(nullptr), right(nullptr) {}
 *     TreeNode(int x, TreeNode *left, TreeNode *right) : val(x), left(left), right(right) {}
 * };
 */
class Solution {
public:
    bool isValidBST(TreeNode* root) {
        stack<TreeNode*> stk;
        TreeNode* node = root, *prv = NULL;
        // stk.push(root);
        while(!stk.empty() || node) {
            if(node) {
                stk.push(node);
                node = node->left;
            } else {
                node = stk.top();
                stk.pop();
                if(prv != NULL && prv -> val >= node->val)
                    return false;
                prv = node;
                node = node->right;
            }
        }
        return true;
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Determine if a given binary tree is a valid binary search tree (BST). A BST is valid if, for every node, its left subtree values are less than the node value, and its right subtree values are greater than the node value.

item.title: Leetcode 99: Recover Binary Search Tree
item.description:
Problem Link

Code:

class Solution {
    TreeNode *prv = NULL, * fst = NULL , *scd = NULL;
    void inorder(TreeNode* node)
    {
        if(!node) return;
        inorder(node->left);
        if (prv && node->val < prv->val) {
            if (!fst)  fst = prv;
            scd = node; 
        }
        prv = node;
        inorder(node->right);
    }
public:
    void recoverTree(TreeNode* node) {
        inorder(node);
        swap(fst->val, scd->val);
    }
};

Problem Statement Link to heading

Two nodes in a binary search tree (BST) have been swapped by mistake, violating the BST property. This function identifies and corrects the swapped nodes to restore the BST.
